awd_titl_txt: STEM Learning and Research (STELAR) Center: A Resource Center to Support Research and Development on STEM Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
This Learning and Research Center will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by providing technical support to all ITEST projects, facilitating national dissemination of ITEST project outcomes, and further developing the ITEST research and development community.  The primary goals of the Center are to: a) increase the capacity of ITEST project teams and evaluators to effectively synthesize and disseminate project findings; b) increase national awareness and use of ITEST project findings; c) strengthen and expand the ITEST community of practice; d) further engage individuals and institutions currently underrepresented in the ITEST community of practice; and e) strengthen collaborative activities across resource networks to leverage NSF cross-program initiatives.  The Center's highly targeted outreach and dissemination activities will promote widespread implementation and examination of new, evidence-based innovations in formal and informal education for youth in fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).   

In partnership with the National Association of State Directors of Career Technical Education Consortium, Education Development Center will host the ITEST Learning and Resource Center and work with nationally recognized career development researchers to increase the capacity of ITEST projects to integrate sound career theory, research findings, and best practices into their planned activities.  In response to documented national needs in the STEM workforce, the Center will promote increased attention to "middle-level" STEM careers and education pathways to those careers.   The Center will also establish a Broadening Participation Advisory Council to assist the Center with outreach and engagement of minority serving organizations and communities.  These efforts will be supported and enhanced through a variety of activities intended to strengthen and expand the Center's Innovation Network, including the provision of mini-grants to selected Principal Investigator's to promote dissemination of innovative practices, implementation of a Fellows and mentoring program for ongoing development of expertise among ITEST researchers, development and publication of research syntheses associated with the ITEST guiding questions for research, and production of a variety of Webinars, videos, data briefs, and social media activities to inform the ITEST community of practice and promote active collaboration across active ITEST projects.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The STEM Learning and Research (STELAR) Center builds capacity and magnifies the results of ITEST projects, promoting the transfer of research-to-practice in STEM education to deepen the impact of the ITEST program. Since 2003 EDC and the ITEST program have successfully served 516 current and past ITEST projects reaching individuals in all 50 states including approximately 1.5 million students, 60,000 teachers, and 20,000 parents and caregivers.

EDC provides leadership in sustaining a thriving, highly engaged community of ITEST principal investigators (PIs), project staff, and evaluators; implementing a well-regarded model of technical support; raising the national visibility of the ITEST program and the collective impact of its grantees; disseminating key project findings to the field through journal articles, conference presentations, data briefs, public webinars, and social media; and broadening participation in the ITEST CoP through carefully structured, targeted proposal development workshops and related activities nationally.

STELAR builds and sustains a thriving Community of Practice (CoP) by meeting regularly with ITEST projects to discuss emerging topics of interest and share experiences, expanding the ITEST CoP across related NSF communities, and building shared ownership and leadership of activities and resources. On average, 87% of more than 150 active ITEST projects complete an annual survey that gathers information on project activities, participants, research questions, successes, and challenges to inform the community and NSF on the state of the ITEST program. Annual ITEST Summits bring together more than 200 ITEST PIs, evaluators, and NSF program officers for two days of knowledge sharing and capacity building. Evaluations report consistently successful summits, with attendees finding meetings valuable with significant professional impact. Through STELAR-initiated quarterly cross-resource-center meetings 10 EHR and CISE resource center leaders meet regularly, deepening collaborative activities to leverage NSF cross-program investments, extending the reach of centers' dissemination networks, and brokering connections across program communities to synergistically advance network goals.

Through technical support STELAR increases the capacity of ITEST PIs and evaluators to design, evaluate, and refine their projects and to effectively synthesize and disseminate project findings. STELAR serves ITEST projects from proposal development to publication of findings through TA webinars (e.g. Writing Successful Annual Reports, Effective Dissemination Plans, The New Face of Research and Evaluation, etc.), webinars presented by NSF program officers (e.g., ITEST Solicitation), and sharing of resources on the STELAR website (e.g., curated proposal development resources, archived webinars, a people connector directory).

STELAR raises the visibility of ITEST by increasing awareness and use of findings from the ITEST program portfolio. STELAR's website shares 483 project profiles, 154 research and/or evaluation instruments, 80 curricular materials, and 412 publications written by ITEST-funded projects or relevant to the ITEST community.  In a special ITEST issue of the Journal of Science Education and Technology, edited by STELAR, 16 ITEST authored articles offered research-based insights into the knowledge generated by a decade of ITEST funded work.  In a series of four reports STELAR synthesized findings from more than 200 publications written by 110 ITEST project staff over 13 years in response to Guiding Questions for Research named in prior ITEST solicitations. STELAR published five infographic-rich reports to share current ITEST project methods, activities, and successes, and up-to-date snapshots of the ITEST portfolio. STELAR submitted conference symposium proposals helping projects to share their work and ignite education exchange.  Since 2003 STELAR supported ITEST PIs as they conducted more than 250 information-sharing visits with legislators on Capitol Hill as part of our annual Summits. STELAR communications highlights include an 80% increase in twitter followers (1490) earning over 750,000 twitter impressions; email subscription growth of 70% (6,000) with an open rate of 30% exceeding industry standard; and attracted 306K website visitors, increasing unique visitors by 177%, and page views by 155% (691K).  

STELAR broadens participation by engaging individuals and institutions currently underrepresented in the ITEST leadership community and CoP through targeted outreach activities to MSIs; and increasing capacity of ITEST projects to recruit and retain student participants from underserved groups. STELAR's communications strategy engages a broad audience of individuals through the use of carefully selected channels including our website (stelar.edc.org) as well as leveraging other websites (e.g., edc.org, edc.cadrek12.org, circlcenter.org, caise.org, includesnetwork.org, etc.), a social media strategy that engages other NSF centers and networks, and a newsletter through which STELAR highlights ITEST project work; shared ITEST projects' publications, curricular materials, and research/evaluation instruments; announced relevant funding and dissemination opportunities; and broadcasted STEM workforce education news. In 2017 STELAR developed an online ITEST proposal development course which has served 153 proposal writers; 82% reported belonging to groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM, and 41% were located at minority-serving institutions. STELAR instituted an ITEST Fellows program in 2017 to build capacity of potential ITEST PIs from communities underrepresented in the ITEST portfolio. 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Sarita Nair-Pillai
